abstracts.cdata!:
The Infrastructure Engineering Project
            in Lesotho was achieved. The Bank's performance was
            somewhat unsatisfactory in the identification phase,
            satisfactory in the preparation and appraisal phases, and
            highly successful during the three years of implementation.
            The Borrower's performance was satisfactory in project
            identification, preparation, appraisal, and covenant
            compliance. The Borrower's performance during project
            implementation was also satisfactory although there were
            some weaknesses in project coordination. All initially
            planned studies were completed and procedures for allocating
            available funds for investment and maintenance in line with
            economic criteria were developed. The key lesson learned
            from the implementation of the project are: In order to
            ensure the quality of studies and the efficiency of
            training, activities must take place within a comprehensive
            manpower development strategy, and trained staff must be
            evaluated through an agreed upon mechanism.

docna.cdata!:
Lesotho - Infrastructure Engineering Project
            : Credit 2400 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Lesotho - Infrastructure
            Engineering Project : Credit 2400 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the
            Infrastructure Engineering Project is to increase the
            economic benefits derived from infrastructure investments in
            the roads, urban water and sewerage, and public buildings
            sectors.  The project will comprise of the following
            components: (1) the roads component, which will strengthen
            the capacity to plan, construct and maintain Lesotho's
            road network; (2) the water and sewerage component, which
            will reinforce the ability to meet customer demand for water
            and sewerage services, particularly in the Maseru urban
            area; (3) the public buildings component, which will develop
            the capacity to maintain public buildings by developing
            maintenance assessment, engineering studies for
            rehabilitation, and restoration of selected public
            buildings.  In addition to these three components, the
            project will provide technical assistance for project
            management and accounting.
